In defense, Orillo claimed an alibi, stating he was in Bicol for a town fiesta and baptism on the date of the posting, while Danieles claimed he was merely a spectator and was only included in the complaint because he refused to testify against his co-accused
Decision: The Supreme Court affirmed the petitioners' conviction for Libel, finding that the elements of the crime were proven beyond reasonable doubt. The Court rejected the defense of alibi and denial, upholding the findings of the lower courts that petitioners' defenses were weak and uncorroborated, noting that it was not physically impossible for Orillo to have been at the crime scene. The Court found all elements of libel present: the imputation (carnapping) was defamatory as it discredited Cabatian's character, it was published by posting it on a public bulletin board, Cabatian was clearly identifiable, and the act was done with malice. The malice was evident because the posting occurred a month after the election, thus serving no purpose other than to injure Cabatian's reputation and expose him to ridicule, particularly since the petitioners were his losing rivals. However, the Court modified the penalty in line with prevailing jurisprudence that favors the imposition of a fine instead of imprisonment for libel.
Ruling: The Petition for Review is DENIED. The July 23, 2012 Decision and April 18, 2013 Resolution of the Court of Appeals are AFFIRMED with MODIFICATION. In lieu of imprisonment, petitioners Junar D. Orillo and Florencio E. Danieles are instead sentenced to pay a FINE in the amount of P6,000.00 with subsidiary imprisonment in case of insolvency. The award of attorney's fees by the trial court was DELETED, while the order to pay moral damages to Romeo Cabatian in the amount of Twenty Thousand (P20,000.00) was AFFIRMED.
Verdict: Petitioners Junar D. Orillo and Florencio E. Danieles are found GUILTY of the crime of Libel.

Case Title: JUDGE RODERICK A. MAXINO, COMPLAINANT, VS. JAIME M. JASMIN, LEGAL RESEARCHER II, BRANCH 43, REGIONAL TRIAL COURT, TANJAY CITY, NEGROS ORIENTAL, RESPONDENT.
Facts: This administrative matter arose after the Supreme Court dismissed an initial complaint for usurpation of authority filed by Judge Roderick A. Maxino against Jaime M. Jasmin (respondent), a Legal Researcher II. Following the dismissal, Jasmin requested the Court to process his back salaries and allow him to return to work, attaching medical certifications. The Judicial Integrity Board (JIB) investigated and found that while Jasmin's application for sick leave for July 2018 was approved by the Supreme Court's Medical Services, he had continuously failed to report for work since August 2018 (going on Absence Without Official Leave, or AWOL). Since the respondent was neither prevented nor disallowed from reporting for work during this time, his prolonged unauthorized absence caused disruption to the functions of his office.
Decision: The Supreme Court adopted and approved the findings and recommendation of the JIB. The Court clarified that the procedure to drop an employee from the rolls due to AWOL is non-disciplinary in nature and is governed by the 2017 Rules on Administrative Cases in Civil Service (RACCS), not Rule 140 of the Rules of Court. Citing Section 107(a)(1) of the 2017 RACCS, which allows for separation if an employee is continuously absent without official leave for at least thirty (30) working days, the Court ruled that Jasmin's continuous unauthorized absence since August 2018 warranted his separation from service. Consequently, the Court denied Jasmin's request to return to work.
Ruling: The Court DROPS respondent Jaime M. Jasmin, Legal Researcher II, Branch 43, Regional Trial Court, Tanjay City, Negros Oriental, from the rolls effective August 1, 2018, and his position is declared VACANT. However, since the separation is non-disciplinary, Jasmin is still qualified to receive the benefits he may be entitled to under existing laws until July 31, 2018, and may still be reemployed in the government.
Verdict: The Supreme Court found that respondent Jaime M. Jasmin was continuously absent without official leave (AWOL) for at least thirty (30) working days since August 2018, which is a sufficient ground for separation from service.

Case Title: NATIONAL POWER CORPORATION, PETITIONER, VS. PROVINCIAL GOVERNMENT OF BULACAN, GLORIA P. STA. MARIA, MUNICIPAL ASSESSOR OF NORZAGARAY, AND THE MUNICIPAL GOVERNMENT OF NORZAGARAY, BULACAN, RESPONDENTS
Facts: The National Power Corporation (NPC), a government-owned and controlled corporation (GOCC) operating the Angat Hydro-Electric Power Plant, received two Notices of Assessment for Real Property Tax (RPT) from the Municipal Government of Norzagaray, Bulacan: the Machineries Assessment (1996-2005) and the Land Assessment (1997-2006). NPC questioned the assessment before the Local Board of Assessment Appeals (LBAA). NPC argued that the properties listed in the Machineries Assessment were exempt from RPT under the Local Government Code (LGC) because they are actually, directly, and exclusively used for generating and transmitting electricity. Regarding the Land Assessment, NPC questioned the correctness of the assessed value. Critically, NPC did not pay the tax under protest before filing its appeal, asserting that the payment-under-protest requirement does not apply when questioning the assessor's authority to impose the tax on an exempt property. The LBAA and the Central Board of Assessment Appeals (CBAA) upheld the tax assessments, ruling that the properties were not exclusively used for power generation and that payment under protest was mandatory.
Decision: The Supreme Court DENIED NPC's petition. The Court ruled that NPC's claim for tax exemption (whether full or partial) does not question the assessor's authority to impose the tax, but rather the correctness or reasonableness of the assessment. A claim of exemption requires presenting factual evidence (e.g., proving the actual, direct, and exclusive use of the machinery) to the administrative bodies. When the issue is a question of fact or the correctness of the assessment, the requirement of "payment under protest" under Section 252(a) of the LGC is mandatory and a condition precedent. NPC’s failure to pay the assessed RPT under protest rendered its administrative appeal without effect, meaning the LBAA and subsequent appellate bodies lacked the authority to take cognizance of the case. Thus, the CTA En Banc correctly dismissed the appeal for lack of cause of action.
Ruling:
The Petition for Review on Certiorari is hereby DENIED. The Decision dated November 29, 2012, and the Resolution dated April 22, 2013, of the Court of Tax Appeals En Banc in CTA EB No. 850, which affirmed the assessments, are AFFIRMED. Accordingly, the National Power Corporation is directed to pay the Municipality of Norzagaray, Bulacan, its tax liabilities amounting to:

PHP 18,475,003.20 over the "Land Assessments" (covering January 1, 1997 to December 31, 2006).

PHP 113,960,000.00 over the "Machineries Assessment" (covering January 1, 1996 to December 31, 2005).
Verdict: The Supreme Court found that the National Power Corporation (NPC) failed to comply with the mandatory condition precedent of paying the assessed Real Property Tax under protest, which is required when contesting the correctness of an assessment based on a claim of exemption.

Case Title: GLEN ORDA Y LOYOLA, PETITIONER, VS. PEOPLE OF THE PHILIPPINES, RESPONDENT.
Facts: Petitioner Glen Orda y Loyola was charged with three separate violations of Republic Act No. 9165 (Comprehensive Dangerous Drugs Act): Section 5 (selling 0.310 gram of shabu), Section 11 (possession of 0.164 gram of shabu), and Section 12 (possession of drug paraphernalia). Petitioner sought to enter into plea bargaining in all three cases under the Supreme Court's framework (A.M. No. 18-03-16-SC), proposing to plead guilty to lesser offenses (two counts of Section 12 and one count of Section 15, which is for use). The prosecution objected, citing the Department of Justice (DOJ) Circular No. 27, which set stricter limits on plea bargaining, particularly barring a plea bargain for Section 5 to anything other than Section 11(3). The Trial Court granted the plea bargaining proposal, citing the Supreme Court's rule-making power. However, the Court of Appeals (CA) initially affirmed the trial court but later reversed itself upon reconsideration by the prosecution, ordering the cases to proceed to trial based on the required mutual consent for plea bargaining.
Decision:
The Supreme Court REVERSED the CA's Amended Decision and reinstated the validity of the plea bargaining, but with a remand for qualification assessment. The Court referenced its recent consolidated rulings (People v. Montierro and Baldadera v. People) which reconciled the conflicting circulars. The Court noted that the DOJ had since issued DOJ Circular No. 18 (2022), aligning the prosecution's plea bargaining framework with the Supreme Court's A.M. No. 18-03-16-SC. This alignment meant that the prosecution's original objection, based solely on the superseded DOJ Circular No. 27, was effectively withdrawn.

However, the Court emphasized that while the trial court has the discretion to approve a plea bargain over a baseless prosecution objection, it must first determine whether the accused is qualified under the Montierro guidelines. This qualification involves assessing whether: (a) the evidence of guilt is strong, and (b) the accused has disqualifying circumstances (e.g., recidivism, habitual offender status, or a history of drug relapses). Therefore, the case must be remanded to allow the trial court to make this necessary factual determination regarding the petitioner's qualification.
Ruling:
The Petition is DENIED (insofar as it sought outright final approval of the plea bargain). The Amended Decision of the Court of Appeals dated July 21, 2021, which annulled the plea bargain and ordered trial, is REVERSED.

The Supreme Court REMANDS Criminal Case Nos. C-87-16, C-88-16, and C-89-16 to the Regional Trial Court of Roxas City, Branch 16, with an order to:

Determine the qualification of Glen Orda y Loyola to avail of the benefits of plea bargaining under the guidelines set forth in People v. Montierro.

Resolve anew his plea bargaining proposals based on that determination.
Verdict: The Supreme Court found that the prosecution's objection to the plea bargaining, being based on the subsequently superseded DOJ Circular No. 27, was invalid. However, the Court found that the Trial Court had hastily approved the plea bargain without first determining the petitioner's qualification under the rules.

Case Title: PEOPLE OF THE PHILIPPINES, PLAINTIFF-APPELLEE, VS. BALTAZAR ACHAY, JR. Y DOCIL, ACCUSED-APPELLANT.
Facts: Accused-appellant Baltazar Achay, Jr. (Achay) was charged in four separate Informations stemming from a shooting incident on September 6, 2013, in Tondo, Manila. Achay was charged with: 1) Murder for the death of Barangay Chairperson Rolando Reyes; 2) Attempted Murder for the non-fatal shooting of Chairperson Reyes's wife, Marilou Estrella Reyes; 3) Attempted Murder for the shooting of Juanito Fausto, Jr.; and 4) Violation of Section 10(a) of R.A. No. 7610 (Child Abuse) for the minor injury sustained by two-year-old Adrian Dagulo. The prosecution's evidence relied on multiple eyewitnesses who positively identified Achay as the gunman who shot the victims at the barangay hall and later in the street. Achay maintained his innocence, claiming the defense of alibi, arguing he was at home at the time of the incident, and claiming his subsequent warrantless arrest was illegal. The Trial Court acquitted Achay of the attempted murder and R.A. 7610 charges, but convicted him of the lesser crimes of Less Serious Physical Injuries (for Marilou), Slight Physical Injuries (for Dagulo and Fausto), and Murder (for Rolando Reyes). The Court of Appeals later reinstated the charge against Fausto to Attempted Murder, while affirming the other convictions.
Decision: The Supreme Court AFFIRMED the conviction of Achay, finding no reason to disturb the lower courts' rulings. The Court upheld the principle that the defense of denial and alibi cannot outweigh the positive identification made by credible eyewitnesses, noting that Achay failed to prove the physical impossibility of his presence at the crime scene. Furthermore, the Court clarified that even if Achay's warrantless arrest had been illegal, his subsequent conviction was supported by the overwhelming testimony of the eyewitnesses, which was independent of the legality of the arrest or the admissibility of the seized firearm. The Court agreed with the CA's finding of treachery in the killing of Chairperson Rolando Reyes, upholding the conviction for Murder. For Fausto's case, the SC modified the CA's conviction from Attempted Murder back down to Attempted Homicide, finding that the prosecution failed to prove the qualifying circumstances of treachery and evident premeditation necessary for murder, but that Achay clearly intended to kill Fausto to facilitate his escape. The Court affirmed the convictions for Less Serious Physical Injuries for Marilou and Slight Physical Injuries for Dagulo.
Ruling:
The Decision of the Court of Appeals is AFFIRMED with MODIFICATION. Achay is sentenced and ordered to pay the following:

For Murder (Crim. Case No. 13-300493): Penalty of Reclusion Perpetua, and ordered to pay the heirs of Rolando Reyes P75,000.00 each for civil indemnity, moral damages, and exemplary damages, plus P44,225.00 for actual damages.

For Attempted Homicide (Crim. Case No. 13-300492): Indeterminate penalty of four (4) months of arresto mayor (minimum) to four (4) years and two (2) months of prision correccional (maximum), and ordered to pay Juanito Fausto, Jr. P20,000.00 each for civil indemnity and moral damages, plus P707.00 for actual damages.

For Less Serious Physical Injuries (Crim. Case No. 13-300491): Imprisonment for four (4) months, and ordered to pay Marilou Estrella Reyes P1,066.00 for actual damages and P5,000.00 for moral damages.

For Slight Physical Injuries (Crim. Case No. 13-300490): Imprisonment for twenty (20) days, and ordered to pay Adrian Dagulo P4,565.00 for actual damages and P5,000.00 for moral damages.

All damages shall bear interest at the rate of six percent (6%) per annum from the finality of the Decision until fully paid.
Verdict:
Accused-appellant Baltazar Achay, Jr. y Docil is found GUILTY beyond reasonable doubt of the following crimes:

Murder (for the death of Rolando Reyes).

Attempted Homicide (for the injury sustained by Juanito Fausto, Jr.).

Less Serious Physical Injuries (for the injury sustained by Marilou Estrella Reyes).

Slight Physical Injuries (for the injury sustained by Adrian Dagulo).

Case Title: THE CITY GOVERNMENT OF CALOOCAN, PETITIONER, VS. CARMEL DEVELOPMENT INC., RESPONDEN
Facts:
Since 1958, Carmel Development, Inc. (CDI) has been the registered owner of land where Pangarap Village is located. In 1973, Presidential Decree No. 293 (PD 293) declared CDI’s titles void and opened the lots for disposition to alleged occupants. However, in 1988, the Supreme Court, in the case of Tuason v. Register of Deeds, declared PD 293 unconstitutional and void ab initio, thereby restoring full ownership to CDI. Following the restoration of its title, CDI installed security measures, including road blockades and security booms, along Gregorio Araneta Avenue, a major thoroughfare within the village that CDI claimed as private property.

In January 2016, the City Government of Caloocan filed a Complaint for Abatement of Nuisance with prayer for injunction, arguing that CDI's road blockades were a public nuisance under the Civil Code because they endangered the welfare of residents and hampered the delivery of basic government services (police, fire, health, and utilities). The Regional Trial Court (RTC) granted the City's application for a writ of preliminary injunction, ruling that the City had a right to unhampered access and that CDI was estopped from denying access because it had tolerated the presence of government facilities for nearly 30 years after the Tuason ruling.
Decision:
The Supreme Court DENIED the City Government of Caloocan's petition, thereby AFFIRMING the Court of Appeals' (CA) decision to dissolve the injunction. The Court ruled that the City failed to establish the two essential requisites for a writ of preliminary injunction:

Clear and Unmistakable Right: While the City has a right to possess the government facilities and structures it built (which must be compensated to CDI, as the land has been dedicated to public use under the Malonesio doctrine), it failed to prove that this right was substantially invaded. The City admitted that CDI had not totally prevented access, but merely regulated it, noting the existence of other backroads, albeit inconvenient.

Material and Substantial Invasion: The relative inconvenience caused by securing permission for entry did not constitute a material and substantial invasion of the City's right. The restriction was a valid exercise of CDI's ownership rights under Article 429 of the Civil Code, which allows an owner to use reasonable force (such as security barriers) to repel actual or threatened unlawful physical invasion or usurpation of private property.

Furthermore, the Court held that the RTC's issuance of the injunction had the effect of changing the status quo (the regulated access existing at the time the case was filed) rather than preserving it, which exceeds the scope of a preliminary injunction.
Ruling: The Petition for Review on Certiorari is DENIED. The Court of Appeals' October 20, 2017 Decision and the June 20, 2018 Resolution in CA-G.R. SP. No. 147019 are AFFIRMED.
Verdict: The Supreme Court found that the City Government of Caloocan failed to establish the legal requisites for the issuance of a writ of preliminary injunction, specifically the existence of a clear and unmistakable right to unhampered access and a material and substantial invasion of that right. The Court affirmed that the road blockades, though inconvenient, did not constitute a judicially abatable nuisance given the circumstances of private ownership.

Case Title: ALMA C. LUGAWE, PETITIONER, VS. PACIFIC CEBU RESORT INTERNATIONAL, INC., RESPONDENT.
Facts:
Ms. Lugawe was hired by Pacific Cebu Resort International, Inc. (“PCRI”) as an accounting clerk in March 2000 and promoted to HR Officer/Manager on January 1, 2007. 

 In October 2013, PCRI underwent a change in ownership/management, and several key human-resources and administrative functions previously under Lugawe’s office (such as compensation & benefits, administration of security services, supervision of company drivers, hiring discretion) were transferred to other departments. 

 Lugawe claimed these changes effectively stripped her of meaningful duties and responsibilities, making her continued employment untenable, and filed a complaint for constructive dismissal (with claims for separation pay, 13th month pay, and other benefits) on December 13, 2013. 

 PCRI countered that Lugawe retained her title, salary, and benefits, and that the transfers were valid exercises of management prerogative. Furthermore, PCRI contended that Lugawe abandoned her job when she failed to report for work after her approved sick leave and did not respond to a letter requesting explanation—hence they considered her employment terminated by abandonment.
Decision:
The Court held that the transfer of HR functions from Lugawe’s office was a valid exercise of management prerogative in furtherance of legitimate business interests (improving internal controls, organizational efficiency), and that Lugawe retained her rank, salary, and benefits, which meant there was no demotion in rank or diminution in pay. 
 The Court further concluded that Lugawe’s prolonged, unexplained absence from work, her failure to respond to a letter demanding explanation, and communications indicating she would no longer report for duty constituted abandonment of her employment.
Ruling: The petition for review on certiorari was denied, the ruling of the Court of Appeals that Lugawe voluntarily resigned / abandoned her employment was AFFIRMED.
Verdict: Ms. Lugawe was not constructively dismissed; rather, the employment relationship was terminated by abandonment, and she is not entitled to separation pay on the ground of constructive dismissal.

Case Title: EDWARD N. RIVO, PETITIONER, VS. DOLORES S. RIVO, RESPONDENT.
Facts:
Edward N. Rivo (the petitioner) and Dolores S. Rivo (the respondent) were office colleagues who began dating in 1978, entered into a civil marriage on January 19, 1979 and a church wedding on March 14, 1979. 
Prior to the marriage, Dolores had a child with a former partner whom Edward accepted as his own. 

 They had three children of their own. On April 26, 2005, Edward filed a Petition for Declaration of Nullity of Marriage under Article 36 of the Family Code, alleging that Dolores was psychologically incapable of fulfilling her essential marital obligations from the time of the marriage, though he only discovered this later. 

 He claimed that during the marriage Dolores gave priority to the family grocery business (managed by her family) rather than spending time with him or the children, neglected her personal appearance and hygiene to such an extent that he lost the desire for intimacy, and was unfair to one of the children (Jor-el) favouring the others. 
On his part, Edward admitted to two extra-marital affairs and fathering two children with a mistress (Perla), and that he abandoned his family for two years starting in 1989. 
 A clinical psychologist (Dr. Natividad Dayan) evaluated the parties and opined that Edward had Narcissistic Personality Disorder and that Dolores had a Compulsive Personality Disorder, and that their marriage was afflicted by partner relational problems. 

 In contrast, Dolores denied the allegations, insisted she was a model wife and mother, that she spent time with her family (her mother looked after the grocery on Sundays), and that their sexual life was normal until Edward began his affairs. 

 The Regional Trial Court (RTC) granted Edward’s petition on October 30, 2009, declaring the marriage void ab initio on grounds of psychological incapacity. 

 The Court of Appeals (CA) on September 9, 2013 reversed the RTC decision, finding the proof insufficient to show psychological incapacity; it observed that Edward’s infidelity, dissatisfaction and desertion were the real reasons for the failure of the marriage
Decision: The Court of Appeals held that the totality of evidence before the RTC did not satisfy the parameters for psychological incapacity: specifically it found that the petitioner had been faithful and functional for many years prior to his affair; his abandonment and extramarital relationship were not the product of a pre-existing, durable personality structure incapacitating him psychologically. It also held that mere infidelity and abandonment do not constitute psychological incapacity under Article 36.
Ruling: The Supreme Court affirmed the CA decision. It found procedural infirmity (lack of verification and certificate against forum-shopping) but also on the merits held that petitioner failed to show psychological incapacity as defined in the jurisprudence (existing at the time of marriage, durable personality structure, genuine serious psychic cause, clear and convincing evidence). It held that the evidence showed dissatisfaction and infidelity rather than incapacity.
Verdict: The petition for review on certiorari was denied, and the reversal of the RTC decision by the Court of Appeals was affirmed, meaning the marriage stands and no declaration of nullity was granted.

Case Title: DEVELOPMENT BANK OF THE PHILIPPINES, PETITIONER, VS. MONSANTO COMPANY, RESPONDENT.
Facts: The respondent corporations had transacted business in the Philippines by selling acrylic fiber (from 1978 to 1983) and were alleged to have operated without the proper license under the pertinent Foreign Investments law.
Decision: The Court of Appeals affirmed the decision of the Regional Trial Court that the respondents were indeed doing business without the required license, and liability therefore attached.
Ruling:
The Court of Appeals affirmed the decision of the Regional Trial Court that the respondents were indeed doing business without the required license, and liability therefore attached. 

Ruling: The Supreme Court of the Philippines upheld the lower courts’ findings, rejecting arguments that the respondents were exempt or that the sale transactions were simply export-activities rather than business operations in the Philippines.
Verdict: The respondents were held liable for operating without a license and the petition by the Development Bank of the Philippines was granted; the decision of the lower courts was affirmed.

Case Title: I-PEOPLE MANPOWER RESOURCES, INC., ELEC QATAR AND LEOPOLDO GANGOSO, JR., PETITIONERS, VS. COURT OF APPEALS AND JOMER O. MONTON, RESPONDENTS.
Facts:
On June 24, 2013, Elec Qatar, a Qatar-based company offering electro-­mechanical services, hired Monton as one of its electrical engineers through its local manpower agency, I-People Manpower Resources, Inc. (IPMR).[6]

Monton and Elec Qatar executed an employment contract for two years, from November 9, 2013 to November 9, 2015, with a monthly basic salary of QAR 6,000.00 and an allowance of QAR 3,000.00.[7] His employment contract stipulated that he will be assigned to the State of Qatar. The contract also provided that Elec Qatar could terminate the contract by giving a one-month prior written notice to Monton.[8]

On November 7, 2013, Monton flew to Qatar and started his work on November 9, 2013. Monton subsequently paid IPMR the placement fees in the amounts of QAR 2,000.00, QAR 2,260.00, and QAR 2,000.00, or a total amount of QAR 6,260.00. These amounts were deducted from Monton's salary for July, September, and October 2014.[9]

Thereafter, Monton received a letter from Elec Qatar on October 6, 2014, informing him that his employment contract will be terminated within 30 days from the receipt of said letter by reason of the low activity in the company and the lack of projects, forcing the company to reduce cost and manpower.[10]

On November 4, 2014, Monton sent an e-mail with the subject "Letter of Gratitude" to Elec Qatar's managing director, Claudio Natali, which read:
Dear Sir Claudio,

Prior to the last day of my service I would like to personally thank you towards the support and guidance I've been receiving within my tenure in the organization.

Before I leave, I want to tell you that a year of working with you has bestowed me a further learning and exposure to the industry.

....

Respectfully yours,
Mr. Jomer Monton[11]
On November 10, 2014, Monton was repatriated to the Philippines—a year before the end of his employment contract on November 9, 2015. Then, on November 14, 2014, Monton filed with the Philippine Overseas Employment Agency-Licensing Regulation Office Anti-Illegal Recruitment Branch in Mandaluyong City a request for conciliation of his complaint and grievance against IPMR. Two conferences were conducted from December 10 to 15, 2014. However, the parties failed to reach an agreement.[12]

On December 15, 2014, Monton filed a Complaint for illegal dismissal against IPMR, Elec Qatar, and Leopoldo Gangoso, Jr., the latter being the corporate officer of IPMR (IPMR et al.). Monton prayed for the payment of his salary for the unexpired portion of his employment contract, reimbursement of the placement fee paid to IPMR, damages, and attorney's fees.[13]

Monton asserted that overseas Filipino workers may only be terminated for just or authorized causes, and after compliance with procedural due process. He claimed that he was illegally dismissed since Elec Qatar failed to prove that a valid retrenchment existed. He alleged that the latter was unable to provide evidence of substantial loss in the business, besides bare allegations that the company was experiencing low activity or a shortage of projects.[14]

On the other hand, Elec Qatar argued that there was a valid exercise of management prerogative when it terminated Monton's employment due to retrenchment, as Monton's position as electrical engineer was no longer needed. Moreover, Elec Qatar claimed that the termination was mutually consented to as could be inferred from the e-mail Monton. sent to Elec Qatar's managing director.[15]
Decision: This Court resolves a Petition for Certiorari[1] under Rule 65 of the Rules of Court assailing the Decision[2] and Resolution[3] of the Court of Appeals, which reversed and set aside the Decision[4] and Resolution[5] of the National Labor Relations Commission by declaring that private respondent Jomer O. Monton (Monton) was illegally dismissed from service.
Ruling:
The Petition should be dismissed.

A discussion must first be made on the remedy availed by IPMR et al.

IPMR et al. are assailing the Decision[31] and Resolution[32] of the Court of Appeals via a Petition for Certiorari[33] under Rule 65, as could be understood when IPMR et al. manifested that "[t]his is a special civil action for certiorari under Rule 65 of Revised Rules of Civil procedure, as Amended ..." However, it is worth noting that the caption of the pleading is denominated as a Petition for Review.[34]

It must be emphasized that a petition for review on certiorari under Rule 45 is the proper remedy to assail a judgment, final order, or resolution of the Court of Appeals.[35] On the other hand, a petition for certiorari under Rule 65 is the proper remedy when there is no appeal or when there is no plain, speedy, and adequate remedy available.[36]

In National Irrigation Administration v. Court of Appeals,[37] this Court aptly explained that:
[S]ince the Court of Appeals had jurisdiction over the petition under Rule 65, any alleged errors committed by it in the exercise of its jurisdiction would be errors of judgment which are reviewable by timely appeal and not by a special civil action of certiorari. If the aggrieved party fails to do so within the reglementary period, and the decision accordingly becomes final and executory, he cannot avail himself of the writ of certiorari, his predicament being the effect of his deliberate inaction.

The appeal from a final disposition of the Court of Appeals is a petition for review under Rule 45 and not a special civil action under Rule 65 of the Rules of Court, now Rule 45 and Rule 65, respectively, of the 1997 Rules of Civil Procedure. Rule 45 is clear that decisions, final orders or resolutions of the Court of Appeals in any case, i.e., regardless of the nature of the action or proceeding involved, may be appealed to this Court by filing a petition for review, which would be but a continuation of the appellate process over the original case. Under Rule 45 the reglementary period to appeal is fifteen (15) days from notice of judgment or denial of motion for reconsideration.
Verdict:
It is axiomatic that labor contracts are heavily impressed with public interest, since employers and employees "do not stand on equal footing."[81] The primacy of the law over the nomenclature of the contract and the stipulations contained therein is to uphold the policy outlined in the Constitution of affording full protection to labor.[82] Labor contracts are accorded a higher status than ordinary contracts and are subject to the police power of the State.[83] Article 1700 of the Civil Code further provides that:
The relations between capital and labor are not merely contractual. They are so impressed with public interest that labor contracts must yield to the common good. Therefore, such contracts are subject to the special laws on labor unions, collective bargaining, strikes and lockouts, closed shop, wages, working conditions, hours of labor and similar subjects.[84] (Emphasis supplied)
Otherwise stated, capital and labor may freely stipulate the terms and conditions in labor contracts; however, such contracts are still subject to existing laws and public policy. This Court further explained that:
A contract freely entered into should, of course, be respected, as PIA argues, since a contract is the law between the parties. The principle of party autonomy in contracts is not, however, an absolute principle. The rule in Article 1306, of our Civil Code is that the contracting parties may establish such stipulations as they may deem convenient, "provided they are not contrary to law, morals, good customs, public order or public policy." Thus, counter-balancing the principle of autonomy of contracting parties is the equally general rule that provisions of applicable law, especially provisions relating to matters affected with public policy, are deemed written into the contract. Put a little differently, the governing principle is that parties may not contract away applicable provisions of law especially peremptory provisions dealing with mailers heavily impressed with public interest. The law relating to labor and employment is clearly such an area and parties are not at liberty to insulate themselves and their relationships from the impact of labor laws and regulations by simply contracting with each other.[85] (Emphasis supplied)
In this instance, the employment contract between Elec Qatar and Monton should be read in conjunction with existing laws and jurisprudence. Thus, Monton could only be dismissed if both the substantive and procedural due process requirements under the Labor Code are complied with. Elec Qatar should have substantiated its allegations of retrenchment and served written notice to both the respondent and the appropriate Department of Labor and Employment Regional Office, at least a month before the intended date of the termination specifying the ground thereof,[86] to validly dismiss the respondent.

Regarding the e-mail Monton sent to Elec Qatar's managing director, such is immaterial to the case. It would be unjust if We were to consider Monton's courteous act of sending his appreciation as a form of waiver in seeking legal recourse. The e-mail is merely an acknowledgement of the efforts of his former superior. The fact that Monton acknowledged in his letter that his services were terminated cannot bar him from demanding his claims or from questioning the legality of his dismissal.

Lastly, We agree with the Court of Appeals that IPMR et al.'s actions do not demonstrate bad faith or an intent to undermine Monton's rights. At most, Elec Qatar was simply attempting to exercise its right to pre-terminate the employment contract in accordance with its provisions. As such, We do not believe that an award of moral and exemplary damages is warranted in this case.[87]

FOR THESE REASONS, the Petition is DENIED. The October 15, 2018 Decision and January 24, 2019 Resolution of the Court of Appeals in CA­-G.R. SP No. 144031, are hereby AFFIRMED. Petitioners I-People Manpower Resources, Inc., Elec Qatar and Leopoldo Gangoso, Jr., in his capacity as corporate officer of I-People Manpower Resources, Inc., are ORDERED to PAY private respondent Jomer O. Monton:
(1)	
Seventy-Two Thousand Qatari Riyals (QAR 72,000.00) as private respondent's salaries for the unexpired portion of his employment contract, subject to legal interest of twelve percent (12%) per annum from November 6, 2014 to November 9, 2015 and six percent (6%) per annum from the finality of this Decision;
 	

(2)	
Placement fees with twelve percent (12%) interest per annum from November 6, 2014 to the date that this Decision becomes final and executory; and
 	

(3)	
Attorney's fees equivalent to ten percent (10%) of the total monetary award.
A legal interest rate of six percent (6%) per annum is also hereby imposed on the total judgment award from the date of finality of this Decision until fully paid.

SO ORDERED.

Case Title: CRISOSTOMO B. AQUINO, PETITIONER, VS. AGUA TIERRA ORO MINA (ATOM) DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION, REPRESENTED BY ITS CHAIRMAN & CEO, VIRGILIO A. BOTE, RESPONDENT.
Facts: The dispute involves a seaside parcel of land located on the shores of Boracay Island within Sitio Diniwid, Barangay Balabag, Malay, Aklan. ATOM owns an adjacent three-hectare property and has a pending foreshore lease application over the seaside lot, intending to build a resort-hotel there. ATOM alleged that in 2006, petitioner Aquino illegally took possession of the seaside lot through intimidation and stealth and began constructing permanent concrete structures. Despite repeated requests from ATOM and the local government to stop, Aquino continued his construction activities. ATOM claimed this illegal occupation frustrated their resort-hotel plans and caused foreign investors to withdraw and demand return of investments. ATOM filed an action for recovery of possession, injunction, and damages before the Regional Trial Court of Kalibo, Aklan, arguing that Aquino violated a municipal ordinance and that ATOM had preferential rights as the adjacent property owner. Aquino countered that he purchased the seaside lot in 2005 and that ATOM's claim based on riparian rights had no basis since the lot is located on a cliff facing the sea with no discernible shoreline during low tide, making it not legally classifiable as foreshore land. Aquino claimed the land is forest land under DENR jurisdiction and that his company has a pending Forest Land Use Agreement for Tourism application which was subsequently granted in December 2009. The RTC granted ATOM's preliminary injunction in June 2010 on environmental grounds, which Aquino challenged.
Decision: The Supreme Court granted Aquino's petition and dismissed Civil Case No. 8577 before the Regional Trial Court of Kalibo, Aklan. The Court dissolved the writ of preliminary injunction issued on August 31, 2010.
Ruling: The Supreme Court found several critical errors in the lower courts' decisions. First, the preliminary injunctive writ was improperly issued because ATOM failed to prove a clear legal right to the seaside lot, as the land's classification as foreshore land was disputed and ATOM's title to the adjacent property was itself questionable. Second, the application of the Rules of Procedure for Environmental Cases was erroneous since ATOM's complaint was fundamentally about possession for commercial purposes, not environmental protection, and ATOM intended to conduct the same construction activities it sought to enjoin Aquino from performing. Third, there was no proof that ATOM posted the required bond for the preliminary injunction. Most significantly, the Court held that the DENR had already exercised primary jurisdiction over the matter by classifying the seaside lot as forest land and issuing Aquino's company a Forest Land Use Agreement for Tourism in December 2009. The DENR's determination that the lot was forest land, not foreshore land, was based on technical findings that the area consists of a limestone cliff without a shoreline that alternates between being covered and exposed by tides. The Court ruled that ATOM's claim to preferential rights as a riparian owner failed because the land classification prerequisite for such rights did not exist, as confirmed by the DENR's authoritative determination.
Verdict: The petition was granted. The Court ordered the dismissal of the civil case for lack of cause of action and dissolved the preliminary injunction, recognizing the DENR's primary jurisdiction over public land classification and the validity of the Forest Land Use Agreement for Tourism issued to Aquino's company.

Case Title: PROVINCIAL PROSECUTOR OF ALBAY, PETITIONER, VS. MARIVIC LOBIANO, RESPONDENT.
Facts: Jelyn Galino, a fifteen-year-old minor, filed a criminal complaint against Angeline Morota and Marivic Lobiano for violation of the Anti-Trafficking in Persons Act. Jelyn alleged that she willingly left with Angeline, her fraternity sister and also a minor, believing she would work in a restaurant in Legazpi City. However, Angeline brought her to Sampaguita Bar in Sorsogon, where she was expected to work as a guest relations officer. Marivic, the owner of Sampaguita Bar, asked for identification to verify Jelyn's age, but Angeline answered that Jelyn was nineteen years old. As a guest relations officer, Jelyn was required to drink alcohol and entertain customers, which involved kissing and other lascivious conduct. Her salary depended on how many ladies' drinks she consumed, which were bought by customers. For one month and eight days, she received no salary because she had accumulated a debt of more than three thousand pesos for clothes and beauty products provided by Marivic. Jelyn was only able to leave when her mother, together with police officers, personnel from the Department of Social Welfare and Development, and the media, rescued her from Sampaguita Bar. Of the two respondents, only Angeline submitted a counter-affidavit while Marivic failed to submit any evidence. Angeline claimed that it was actually Jelyn and someone named Danny who recruited her to work as a guest relations officer, contrary to the representation that she would work as a waitress. The Office of the Provincial Prosecutor found probable cause to indict Marivic for Qualified Trafficking but dismissed the charges against Angeline. However, the Regional Trial Court dismissed the case outright for lack of evidence to establish probable cause, finding no proof of conspiracy between Marivic as owner and Jelyn and Danny as recruiters. The Provincial Prosecutor filed a motion for reconsideration arguing that under the law, the act of hiring and receiving a person for prostitution is separate and distinct from recruiting, and no conspiracy is required. After the RTC denied the motion, the Provincial Prosecutor filed a petition for certiorari before the Court of Appeals, which dismissed it for being filed out of time and for being the improper remedy.
Decision: The Supreme Court granted the petition for review on certiorari filed by the Provincial Prosecutor and set aside both the Court of Appeals' resolutions and the Regional Trial Court's order dismissing the criminal case. The Court reinstated the criminal information for Qualified Trafficking filed against Marivic Lobiano.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that the Court of Appeals erred in dismissing the petition for certiorari on procedural grounds. First, the petition was timely filed because it was mailed on February 16, 2015, which was the first working day after the deadline of February 14, 2015 fell on a Saturday, and the date of mailing is considered the date of filing when filing by registered mail. Second, although a petition for certiorari is generally an improper remedy to question a final order dismissing a criminal case, the Court found that exceptions applied in this case because it involved public interest regarding human trafficking, a crime characterized by sexual violence and slavery, and because the RTC's order was a patent nullity constituting grave abuse of discretion. The Court held that the RTC gravely abused its discretion in dismissing the case for lack of probable cause. The evidence clearly established uncontroverted facts that Jelyn was a minor when Marivic received and hired her to work in Sampaguita Bar, Marivic did not take steps to verify Jelyn's age, and the work involved prostitution or lascivious conduct in exchange for money. Under Sections 4(a) and 6(a) of Republic Act No. 9208 as amended, these facts established probable cause for Qualified Trafficking. The Court emphasized that judges may only dismiss cases for lack of probable cause in clear-cut instances when evidence plainly fails to establish probable cause, not when its existence is merely doubtful. Since there was no clear showing of lack of probable cause, and the facts indicated that more likely than not the crime was committed, the dismissal was improper and all parties should be given opportunity to present their claims in a full-blown trial.
Verdict: The petition was granted. The Court set aside the Court of Appeals' July 10, 2015 and April 15, 2016 resolutions as well as the Regional Trial Court's November 13, 2014 order dismissing Criminal Case No. FC-14-1646. The criminal information for Qualified Trafficking against Marivic Lobiano was reinstated, and the trial court was directed to proceed with the arraignment of the accused and trial of the case with dispatch.

Case Title: EDMOND LIM AND GERD PALAND, PETITIONERS, VS. CATALINA SEE, RESPONDENT.
Facts: On March 20, 2000, Chai Seng Ang filed six applications for registration of trademarks with the Intellectual Property Office, including Crown Device, Jowika & Device, Schiso & Device, Device Mark, Crown, and Oro & Device, all used to designate nippers, scissors, nail cutters, cutlery, files, spoons, and knives. On February 26, 2003, Ang filed Assignments of Trademark transferring these applications to Catalina See, who then filed Declarations of Actual Use for the subject marks. In 2004, Edmond Lim learned that See was registering these marks and claimed they were identical to marks owned and used by Gerd Paland for his products, which Lim exclusively distributed in the Philippines. On October 26, 2004, Lim and Paland filed a verified opposition with the IPO Bureau of Legal Affairs. Paland claimed to be the president of Gerd Paland Solingen, a company based in Germany, and asserted he owned the contested marks through his company and predecessor companies that had manufactured and distributed nipper products in Solingen, Germany for fifty years. The marks Schiso and Device had been used since 1970, while Crown, Oro, Jowika, and Stork were used since 1974. Paland obtained registration of these marks in Germany in 2004. Lim and Paland submitted evidence including affidavits, an exclusive distributorship agreement, authenticated German certificates of registration, photographs of products, sales invoices to various countries including the Philippines, and other supporting documents. See countered that she was the proprietor of Lena's Enterprises established in 1981 and had dealt with these nipper brands since then. She claimed that as early as 1968, when she was eight years old, she saw these brands being sold at Nightingale Bazaar owned by her grandfather and managed by her father Joaquin Siy. She testified that her father told her that he and Ang gave or supplied the marks to the nipper products and that these were their brands already known in the market through their efforts. After her father's death in 1981, Lena's Enterprises continued ordering from Ang. In 1999, she received complaints about counterfeit products, prompting Ang to apply for registration in 2000. See claimed Ang voluntarily assigned the trademark applications to her in recognition of the financial support he received from her father and Lena's Enterprises.
Decision: This Court resolves a Petition for Review on Certiorari[1] assailing the Decision[2] and Resolution[3] of the Court of Appeals (CA), which reversed the Decision[4] of the Director General of the Intellectual Property Office. The Office of the Director General-Intellectual Property Office reversed and set aside the Decision[5] rendered by the Bureau of Legal Affairs-Intellectual Property Office which denied the Notice of Opposition filed by Edmond Lim and Gerd Paland (Lim and Paland) against the applications for trademark registration of Catalina See (See). As such, the assailed CA rulings allowed the trademark registration filed by See, except for the mark SCHISO & DEVICE.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that See registered the subject trademarks in bad faith contrary to the requirement of good faith registration under Section 122 of the Intellectual Property Code. The Court clarified that while the first-to-file rule generally applies, it is not absolute and registration must be done in good faith. Bad faith in trademark registration means the applicant has knowledge of prior creation, use, or registration by another of an identical or similar trademark. The Court found that Ang had knowledge of the prior creation and use of the subject trademarks by Paland and his predecessor companies, making the registration an act of trademark squatting. The Court determined that See's entire claim of ownership was founded on hearsay and self-serving statements, with no documentary evidence establishing Ang's ownership of the marks. See's testimony about seeing the products at age eight and her father's alleged statements were insufficient proof. The absence of any business records, correspondence, or evidence of Ang commissioning the manufacture of products as a trademark owner was fatal to her claim. The Court noted that the sales and delivery invoices submitted by Lim and Paland demonstrated that products bearing the subject trademarks were delivered through various distribution channels in the Philippines and abroad for over a decade, with no evidence that other distributors were authorized by Ang. Additionally, See's admission that the Schiso & Device mark did not belong to her father, yet proceeding with the application anyway, demonstrated bad faith. The Court emphasized that registration not in good faith is equivalent to no registration at all, and hence no ownership rights were transmitted. The burden was on See to establish her claim of ownership on the strength of her evidence, which she failed to do.
Verdict: The petition for review was granted. The Court of Appeals' decision and resolution in CA-G.R. SP No. 108067 were reversed and set aside. The decision of the Office of the Director General dated March 13, 2009 was reinstated. Applications for trademark registration bearing serial numbers 4-2000-002135 for Crown Device, 4-2000-002136 for Jowika & Device, 4-2000-002138 for Device Mark, 4-2000-002139 for Crown, and 4-2000-002140 for Oro & Device were denied.

Case Title:
ELENA GAERLAN-OSTONAL, PETITIONER, VS. ROMEO FLORES, RANDY FLORES, HEIRS OF FLORENCIO GAERLAN, THE OFFICE OF THE MUNICIPAL ASSESSOR OF BAUANG, LA UNION, AND THE OFFICE OF THE PROVINCIAL ASSESSOR OF LA UNION, DEFENDANTS,

HEIRS OF EFREN DELIM, RESPONDENTS.
Facts: Elena Gaerlan-Ostonal filed a complaint for cancellation of tax declaration, declaration of nullity of extra-judicial settlement of estate, quieting of title, temporary restraining order and injunction, and damages against Romeo Flores, Randy Flores, the Heirs of Florencio Gaerlan, and the Heirs of Efren Delim. Elena alleged that she was one of the legitimate children and heirs of the late Chan Jut Co, also known as Emiliano Gaerlan or Emiliano Chan, and Gorgonia Gapuz, who were married on January 1, 1913 before Reverend Father Estanislao Filler in Bauang, La Union. Although no record of the marriage was found in the civil registrar or parish office, principal sponsors Pablo Sanchez and Vicente Caluza executed a joint affidavit to prove the marriage existed. On the wedding day, Gorgonia's uncle gifted her a 727-square meter parcel of land in Bauang, La Union, which was declared for tax purposes in Chan Jut Co's name. Elena claimed that Felicidad Gaerlan, Efren Delim, and Romeo Flores, claiming to be compulsory and legal heirs of Chan Jut Co, executed an Extra-Judicial Settlement with Waiver dated March 29, 1983 and adjudicated the subject property among themselves without her knowledge and consent, resulting in the cancellation of the tax declaration in Chan Jut Co's name and transfer to the three defendants. Elena presented various documentary evidence including certifications from the local civil registrar stating that she and her siblings were born to Chan Jut Co and Gorgonia, certification of Emiliano's death stating he was married, and certificates of death from the parish stating Emiliano was married to Gorgonia. The Heirs of Efren contended that Emiliano's legitimate wife was Esperanza Flores, whom he married in the 1900s, and their legitimate children included Maura F. Chan who was the mother of the late Efren. They claimed the subject land was conjugal property of Emiliano and Esperanza, and that they had notorious, public, and open ownership and possession for almost 28 years. The Regional Trial Court ruled in favor of Elena, finding that Emiliano was married to Gorgonia based on documentary evidence and declared the extra-judicial settlement void. However, the Court of Appeals reversed the RTC decision, finding that Elena failed to prove the existence of the marriage between Chan Jut Co and Gorgonia, noting that the documentary evidence were hearsay and that certificates of birth and death only proved parentage and death, not marriage.
Decision: The Supreme Court granted Elena's petition for review on certiorari. The Court reversed and set aside the Court of Appeals' decision dated October 14, 2019 and resolution dated November 24, 2020. The Supreme Court reinstated the Regional Trial Court's decision dated September 19, 2017 with modification regarding legal interest on monetary awards.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that Elena successfully proved her legal title to the subject land as a compulsory heir of Emiliano and that the extra-judicial settlement was void. The Court clarified that pursuant to the doctrine in Treyes v. Larlar, even in ordinary actions, a declaration of heirship may be made to resolve the cause of action without requiring a prior special proceeding for settlement of estate. The Court held that compulsory or intestate heirs may commence an ordinary civil action to declare nullity of a deed and for recovery of property without necessity of a prior and separate judicial declaration of their status as heirs. Regarding the evidence, the Court found that the totality of evidence preponderates in Elena's favor. The certifications from the local civil registrar showing Elena and her siblings were born to Emiliano and Gorgonia, the certification of Emiliano's death showing he was married, and the parish certificates of death were sufficient to prove Elena and her siblings were filiated to Emiliano and therefore his compulsory heirs entitled to the subject land by succession. Conversely, the evidence did not sufficiently show defendants were filiated to Emiliano. The certificate of death stating Maura Flores Dilim's father was Emiliano Chan was insufficient to prove filiation, unlike Elena's birth certifications. Additionally, a Negative Certification of Birth from the National Statistics Office stating there was no record of birth of Maura F. Chan with parents Emiliano and Esperanza further cast doubt on the claimed filiation. The Court emphasized that public documents are prima facie evidence requiring high degree of proof to overcome. Moreover, one defendant, Lolita Gaerlan Calica, testified in favor of Elena through her judicial affidavit, constituting a judicial admission that required no further proof. Regarding the two requisites for quieting of title, the Court found both satisfied: Elena had legal title as a compulsory heir, and the extra-judicial settlement and tax declarations cast cloud on that title. Since defendants failed to prove their filiation to Emiliano, they had no right to settle his estate, making the extra-judicial settlement and resultant tax declarations void ab initio.
Verdict: The petition was granted. The Court of Appeals' decision and resolution in CA-G.R. CV No. 110437 were reversed and set aside. The Regional Trial Court's decision in Civil Case No. 1999-BG was reinstated with modification that the monetary awards due to Elena shall earn legal interest at the rate of six percent per annum from finality of the decision until full payment. The extra-judicial settlement dated March 29, 1983 was declared void ab initio, and the offices of the municipal and provincial assessors were ordered to cancel the tax declarations issued in the names of Romeo Flores, Florencio Gaerlan, and Efren G. Delim.

Case Title: IN RE: PETITION FOR REGISTRATION AND ISSUANCE OF TITLE FOR LOT 2264, LOT 2270 AND LOT 2271 OF THE HIMAMAYLAN CADASTRE, PROVINCE OF NEGROS OCCIDENTAL, AND MIRIAM DURBAN TAGAMOLILA, FOR HERSELF AND AS ATTORNEY-IN-FACT OF HER SISTER CECILIA DIMA-ANO,* PETITIONER, VS. REPUBLIC OF THE PHILIPPINES, RESPONDENT.
Facts: Miriam Durban Tagamolila and her sister Cecilia Durban Dima-ano, as the only legal heirs of their late father Rafael J. Durban, sought to register in their names three parcels of land forming part of Rafael's estate. They filed a petition for original registration of Lot Nos. 2264, 2270, and 2271 of the Himamaylan Cadastre, Province of Negros Occidental before the Regional Trial Court. In their petition, they contended that they were the legal heirs of Rafael, the properties were adjudicated to them by virtue of an Extrajudicial Declaration of Heirship to the Estate of Rafael J. Durban, and Rafael acquired the properties through inheritance from his predecessor as documented in a Petition for Probate of Last Will and Testament on March 23, 1935. The Office of the Solicitor General filed an opposition arguing that the parcels of land were part of the public domain belonging to the Republic of the Philippines, that neither the applicants nor their predecessors-in-interest had been in open, continuous, exclusive and notorious possession since June 12, 1945 or prior thereto, and that the tax declarations and muniments of title did not constitute competent and sufficient evidence of bona fide acquisition or possession. The trial court declared all parties other than the Republic in general default and proceeded to trial. After the parties presented evidence, the Regional Trial Court granted the application for registration, finding that petitioners satisfactorily complied with the requirements for original registration. The Republic appealed, arguing insufficiency of evidence and insisting that land classification as alienable and disposable required certification not only from the City Environment and Natural Resources Office but also from the Secretary of the Department of Environment and Natural Resources. The Court of Appeals granted the Republic's appeal and reversed the trial court, finding the City Environment and Natural Resources certification insufficient to commence the thirty-year prescriptive period, and requiring certificates and approvals from the DENR Secretary that the property formed part of alienable and disposable lands of the public domain.
Decision: The Supreme Court partially granted the petition for review on certiorari. The Court affirmed the Court of Appeals' decision dated February 23, 2015 and resolution dated September 8, 2015 insofar as Tagamolila's adverse possession through her predecessors-in-interest remained uncontested and insofar as substantial compliance with requirements for proof of alienable and disposable nature was unmeritorious. However, the case was remanded to the Court of Appeals for reception of evidence on the subject property's land classification status based on Republic Act No. 11573.
Ruling: The Supreme Court held that the basis for the Court of Appeals' reversal must be recalibrated in view of subsequent developments in the law on original registration of alienable and disposable lands of the public domain, particularly Republic Act No. 11573 and the case of Republic v. Pasig Rizal Co., Inc. The Court ruled that RA 11573 is a curative statute that could be applied retroactively to pending applications for judicial confirmation of title, even without express provisions for retroactivity, because it simplified and harmonized land registration laws and created new rights by shortening the required period of adverse possession from possession since June 12, 1945 to only twenty years immediately preceding the filing of the application. The Court held that the curative nature of RA 11573 could be discerned from its declared purpose to simplify, update and harmonize land laws to remove ambiguity in interpretation and implementation. The Court emphasized that RA 11573 amended the interpretation established in Heirs of Malabanan v. Court of Appeals, particularly the requirement for an express government manifestation that land was no longer intended for public service or development of national wealth. Under the new law, classification of land as alienable and disposable immediately places it within the commerce of man and renders it susceptible to private acquisition through adverse possession, without requiring further express government manifestation. The Court also established that Section 7 of RA 11573 prescribes the nature of proof sufficient to establish land status as alienable and disposable, superseding previous requirements. The Court rejected petitioner's claim of substantial compliance under Republic v. Vega because it applied only on a pro hac vice basis and had been superseded by new guidelines. The Court directed remanded proceedings to focus solely on the issue of the properties' classification as alienable and disposable, with petitioner's evidence of adverse possession limited to evidence already on record, similar to the approach in Pasig Rizal Co., Inc.
Verdict: The petition for review on certiorari was partially granted. The Court of Appeals' decision dated February 23, 2015 and resolution dated September 8, 2015 in CA-G.R. CV No. 03802 were affirmed insofar as Tagamolila's adverse possession through her predecessors-in-interest remained uncontested and substantial compliance with previous requirements was unmeritorious. The case was remanded to the Court of Appeals for reception of evidence on the subject property's land classification status based on the parameters set forth in Section 7 of Republic Act No. 11573, with directions to resolve the case in accordance with the Supreme Court's decision with due and deliberate dispatch.

Case Title: FRANK ONG SIBUMA, PETITIONER, VS. COMMISSION ON ELECTIONS, ALMA L. PANELO, AND STEFANIE ANN ERIGUEL CALONGCAGON, RESPONDENTS.
Facts: Frank Ong Sibuma and Stefanie Ann Eriguel Calongcagon vied for the mayoralty position of the Municipality of Agoo, La Union in the May 9, 2022 National and Local Elections. Sibuma filed his Certificate of Candidacy on October 7, 2021. On November 2, 2021, Alma L. Panelo filed a petition to deny due course to or cancel Sibuma's Certificate of Candidacy under Section 78 of the Omnibus Election Code, alleging that Sibuma committed material misrepresentation by stating in his Certificate of Candidacy that he would be a resident of Barangay Sta. Barbara, Agoo, La Union for one year and three months on the day before the May 9, 2022 Elections, when in truth he was a resident of Zone 2, Purok 9, San Eugenio, Aringay, La Union. To prove her claims, Panelo submitted two certifications dated October 29, 2021 issued by Punong Barangay Erwina C. Eriguel stating that Sibuma was not a resident of Barangay Sta. Barbara, a Deed of Absolute Sale, Transfer Certificate of Title, applications for building permits and licenses showing the address belonged to Eric Ong Sibuma, and a certification from the Municipal Engineer stating no certificate of occupancy had been issued over the property. Sibuma alleged he had established residency in Agoo, La Union since birth and that while he may have been absent for some time, his intention to return had always been shown. He submitted evidence including his Certificate of Live Birth showing he was born in Agoo, his Secondary Student's Record from Don Mariano Marcos State University, telephone bills and electricity bills indicating Sta. Barbara, Agoo as his address, a Tax Declaration of Real Property, and an Affidavit of Residency signed by 41 residents attesting he had resided in Agoo from January 2021. Panelo offered supplementary evidence consisting of affidavits dated December 3 and 4, 2021 individually executed by eight of the 41 affiants recanting their participation in Sibuma's Affidavit of Residency. On May 10, 2022, the Municipal Board of Canvassers proclaimed Sibuma as the duly elected Mayor with 21,364 votes against Eriguel's 16,603 votes. On May 13, 2022, the COMELEC Second Division granted Panelo's petition and cancelled Sibuma's Certificate of Candidacy, ruling he committed material misrepresentation relating to his residency. The COMELEC found that Sibuma failed to establish actual physical presence at Agoo and gave weight to the certifications from the Punong Barangay and the recantation affidavits. On May 24, 2022, the Office of the Clerk of the Commission issued a Certificate of Finality stating the Resolution had become final and executory, noting that Sibuma had not filed any motion for reconsideration within the five-day reglementary period from service via email on May 16, 2022. Sibuma subsequently filed a Motion for Reconsideration on May 27, 2022, alleging he received the Resolution electronically on May 22, 2022. On June 29, 2022, the COMELEC Special Second Division issued a Writ of Execution ordering the annulment of Sibuma's proclamation and the proclamation of Eriguel in his stead.
Decision: The Supreme Court granted the petition for certiorari with prayer for temporary restraining order and writ of preliminary injunction. The Court annulled and set aside the COMELEC Second Division Resolution dated May 13, 2022, the Certificate of Finality dated May 24, 2022, the Entry of Judgment dated May 24, 2022, and the Writ of Execution dated June 29, 2022. The Court denied the petition to deny due course to or cancel Sibuma's Certificate of Candidacy.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that the COMELEC Second Division committed grave abuse of discretion amounting to lack or excess of jurisdiction when it cancelled Sibuma's Certificate of Candidacy and nullified his proclamation as the duly elected Mayor of Agoo, La Union. The Court held that there was no substantial evidence that Sibuma committed a deliberately false and deceptive representation of his residence qualifications in his Certificate of Candidacy. The Court emphasized that for a Section 78 petition to prosper, it is essential that a false representation be committed with a deliberate attempt to mislead, misinform, or hide a fact which would otherwise render a candidate ineligible, meaning it must be made with malicious intent to deceive the electorate. The Court found that the COMELEC failed to make findings of intent to deceive on Sibuma's part. The Court held that Section 74 of the Omnibus Election Code only requires that the facts declared in the Certificate of Candidacy be true to the best of the candidate's knowledge, creating a presumption of good faith in favor of a candidate's declaration under oath. The Court found that Sibuma's declaration of residency proceeded from his good faith and firm belief that he possessed the required residency, as confirmed by his supporting documents. The Court noted that Sibuma's domicile remains in Agoo, La Union where he was born and obtained his secondary education, and that he owns residential house and real properties therein together with his wife. The Court emphasized that absence from legal residence to pursue profession, study or do other things of temporary or semi-permanent nature does not constitute loss of residence, and that the animus revertendi to his home had not forsaken him. The Court also ruled that the COMELEC Second Division made a grossly unreasonable appreciation and evaluation of evidence by shifting the burden of proof upon Sibuma, faulting him for trivial matters, and giving improper weight to evidence such as the pro forma certification from the Punong Barangay who was the paternal aunt of respondent Calongcagon, and affidavits of recantation which should be viewed with suspicion. The Court noted that the COMELEC failed to resolve the petition prior to the May 9, 2022 Elections contrary to Section 78 requirements, and that Sibuma was decisively elected by the people with overwhelming votes, necessitating that doubts should have been resolved in favor of his residence qualification to give fullest effect to the manifest will of the people. The Court emphasized that in any action involving reversal of popular electoral choice, utmost effort must be made to resolve issues in a manner that would give effect to the will of the majority, as it is sound public policy to cause elective offices to be filled by those who are the choice of the majority.
Verdict: The petition was granted. The COMELEC Second Division Resolution dated May 13, 2022, Certificate of Finality dated May 24, 2022, Entry of Judgment dated May 24, 2022, and Writ of Execution dated June 29, 2022 in SPA No. 21-172 (DC) were annulled and set aside. The petition to deny due course to or cancel Sibuma's Certificate of Candidacy was denied. The Certificate of Canvass of Votes and Proclamation of Winning Candidate for Municipal Mayor dated May 10, 2022 proclaiming Frank Ong Sibuma as the duly elected Mayor of the Municipality of Agoo, La Union stands. The Status Quo Ante Order issued by the Court on July 5, 2022 was made permanent.

Case Title:
GLENN QUINTOS ALBANO, PETITIONER, VS. COMMISSION ON ELECTIONS, RESPONDENT.

[UDK No. 17230]

CATALINA G. LEONEN-PIZARRO, PETITIONER, VS. COMMISSION ON ELECTIONS, RESPONDENT.
Facts: Glenn Quintos Albano was the second nominee of Talino at Galing ng Pinoy Party-List for the May 9, 2022 elections. He previously ran for city councilor in Taguig City during the 2019 elections but lost. Catalina G. Leonen-Pizarro was the president and first nominee of the Arts Business and Science Professionals party-list for the 2022 elections. She previously served three consecutive terms as representative from 2007 to 2016, then ran for mayor of Sudipen, La Union in both 2016 and 2019 elections but lost both times. Both petitioners were rendered ineligible to participate in the 2022 elections as party-list nominees because of Section 8 of Republic Act No. 7941 and Sections 5(d) and 10 of COMELEC Resolution No. 10717, which prohibited persons who lost their bid for elective office in the immediately preceding election from being included in the list of party-list nominees. Both petitioners filed separate petitions challenging the constitutionality of these provisions, claiming they violated the Constitution by adding qualifications beyond those prescribed and violated the equal protection clause.
Decision: The Supreme Court granted both petitions and declared unconstitutional the phrase "a person who has lost his bid for elective office in the immediately preceding election" under Section 8 of Republic Act No. 7941, as well as its corresponding phrases in Sections 5(d) and 10 of COMELEC Resolution No. 10717.
Ruling: The Court held that while Congress has the power under Article VI, Section 5(1) of the 1987 Constitution to determine who shall be elected through the party-list system and prescribe qualifications for party-list representatives, any additional qualifications must still comply with the equal protection clause. Applying the rational basis test, the Court found that the challenged provisions failed to demonstrate any rational basis. The classification discriminated against candidates who lost in the previous elections without showing any substantial distinction between them and those who won or did not participate. There was no clear connection between having lost in the immediately preceding election and the probability that such participation would frustrate the policy behind the Party-List System Act, which was to give voice to marginalized and underrepresented sectors. The Court emphasized that no unique circumstance exists attributable to losing candidates in the immediately preceding election that would result in subverting the objective of the party-list system. The prohibition was found to be an arbitrary and whimsical intrusion that violated both the equal protection clause and substantive due process.
Verdict: The Supreme Court declared invalid and unconstitutional the phrase "a person who has lost his bid for elective office in the immediately preceding election" under Section 8 of Republic Act No. 7941, the phrase "have lost in their bid for an elective office in the May 13, 2019 National and Local Elections" under Section 5(d) of COMELEC Resolution No. 10717, and the phrase "or a person who has lost his bid for an elective office in the May 13, 2019 National and Local Elections" under Section 10 of COMELEC Resolution No. 10717. However, the Court clarified that the valid portion of Section 8 remains, which states: "The list shall not include any candidate for any elective office," meaning a person cannot simultaneously run for another elective office while being a party-list nominee in the same election.

Case Title: ANECITA C. SUYAT, ASANO E. ABAN, AND MARCELINO P. ENDI, PETITIONERS, VS. COURT OF APPEALS, OFFICE OF THE OMBUDSMAN, AND COMMISSION ON AUDIT, RESPONDENTS.
Facts: Petitioners Anecita Suyat (Municipal Treasurer), Asano Aban (Municipal Agricultural Officer), and Marcelino Endi (Municipal Accountant) were officials of Buguias, Benguet who were involved in the procurement of insecticides and fungicides worth P1,050,000.00 under the Farm Inputs and Farm Implements Program in June 2004. On June 25, 2004, five days before Mayor Apolinario Camsol's term ended, a Memorandum of Agreement was executed between the Department of Agriculture and the Municipality for the implementation of the program. The procurement was conducted through personal canvass by petitioner Suyat instead of through public bidding as required by Republic Act No. 9184, the Government Procurement Reform Act. The purchase request prepared by petitioner Aban specified brand names of pesticides, which violated the law. Three suppliers submitted bids, with PMB Agro-Goods & Services winning the contract. The Commission on Audit issued an Audit Observation Memorandum noting irregularities, including the absence of public bidding, lack of consultation with farmer-beneficiaries, and overpricing. Subsequently, a Notice of Disallowance was issued declaring the disbursement irregular. Task Force Abono of the Office of the Ombudsman filed a complaint alleging that the procurement violated procurement laws, involved unfair canvassing among different types of distributorships, and that some farmers claimed they never received the supplies or were required to pay 25% of the purchase price to petitioner Aban before release.
Decision: The Supreme Court dismissed the Joint Petition for Certiorari filed by the petitioners and affirmed the Decision dated August 15, 2019 and Resolution dated December 19, 2019 of the Court of Appeals Special 16th Division.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that petitioners used the wrong mode of review by filing a petition for certiorari under Rule 65 instead of a petition for review on certiorari under Rule 45, which is the proper remedy to assail decisions of the Court of Appeals. The Court held that petitioners should have filed their petition within fifteen days from receiving notice of the denial of their motion for reconsideration on January 8, 2020, meaning the deadline was January 23, 2020. However, they filed their petition on March 9, 2020, rendering the Court of Appeals decision final and executory. The Court also ruled that petitioners were not denied due process, as Commission on Audit proceedings do not forestall or postpone the Office of the Ombudsman's independent investigatory powers. The Ombudsman's investigation was based on the complaint filed by Task Force Abono, not solely on the COA audit report, and petitioners had ample opportunity to refute the administrative charges. On the substantive issues, the Court found no reversible error in the findings of the Office of the Ombudsman and Court of Appeals. The procurement violated Republic Act No. 9184's requirement for competitive public bidding, and none of the alternative modes of procurement applied to this case. Even under the old law (Local Government Code of 1991), which allowed personal canvass, petitioners failed to comply with requirements including monetary limitations. The Court emphasized that petitioners, as municipal officials, were duty-bound to know and follow the law, and their ignorance or lack of familiarity with Republic Act No. 9184 was not an excuse. Their actions collectively constituted grave misconduct, conduct prejudicial to the best interest of the service, gross neglect of duty, and less serious dishonesty.
Verdict: The Supreme Court dismissed the Joint Petition for Certiorari and affirmed the Court of Appeals decision finding petitioner Suyat guilty of grave misconduct and conduct prejudicial to the best interest of the service, petitioner Endi guilty of gross neglect of duty and conduct prejudicial to the best interest of the service, and petitioner Aban guilty of grave misconduct, conduct prejudicial to the best interest of the service, and less serious dishonesty. All three petitioners were dismissed from service with cancellation of civil service eligibility, forfeiture of retirement benefits, perpetual disqualification from holding public office, and bar from taking civil service examinations. In the event dismissal could not be enforced due to resignation, retirement, or separation, the penalty would be converted to a fine equivalent to one-year salary. The Court emphasized that high standards of conduct in public service are not mere rhetoric and that public officers who commit serious offenses reflecting unfitness to continue in office must face administrative sanctions to preserve public faith and confidence in government.

Case Title:
ACT TEACHERS REP. ANTONIO TINIO, BAYAN MUNA REP. PARTY-LIST REP. CARLOS ISAGANI ZARATE, AND ANAKPAWIS REP. PARTY-LIST ARIEL "KA AYIK" CASILAO, PETITIONERS, VS. PRESIDENT RODRIGO ROA DUTERTE, HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES SPEAKER PANTALEON ALVAREZ, DEPUTY SPEAKER RANEO ABU, MAJORITY LEADER RODOLFO FARIÑAS, AND DEPUTY MAJORITY LEADER REP. ARTHUR DEFENSOR, JR., RESPONDENTS.

[G.R. No. 236295]

LABAN KONSYUMER, INC. AND ATTY. VICTORIO MARIO A. DIMAGIBA, PETITIONERS, VS. EXECUTIVE SECRETARY SALVADOR C. MEDIALDEA, DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE SECRETARY CARLOS G. DOMINGUEZ III, BUREAU OF INTERNAL REVENUE COMMISSIONER CAESAR R. DULAY, HOUSE SPEAKER PANTALEON D. ALVAREZ IN REPRESENTATION OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES, AND SENATE PRESIDENT AQUILINO D. PIMENTEL III IN REPRESENTATION OF THE SENATE, RESPONDENTS.
Facts: These consolidated petitions challenged the constitutionality of Republic Act No. 10963, also known as the Tax Reform for Acceleration and Inclusion (TRAIN) Act, which was the first package of the Duterte administration's Comprehensive Tax Reform Program intended to fund the government's "Build, Build, Build" program. In G.R. No. 236118, petitioners Tinio, Zarate, and Casilao, who were legislators and principal authors of bills that were eventually substituted by House Bill No. 5636, claimed that the TRAIN Act was unconstitutionally passed when the Bicameral Conference Committee Report was ratified on December 13, 2017 despite an alleged lack of quorum in the House of Representatives. They presented a video recording and photograph showing a near-empty session hall during the ratification. They also argued that President Duterte's signing of the bill into law was tainted with grave abuse of discretion. In G.R. No. 236295, petitioners Laban Konsyumer and Dimagiba filed as consumers claiming to be adversely affected by the pass-on excise taxes on diesel, coal, liquefied petroleum gas, and kerosene imposed by the TRAIN Act.
