Virgilio failed to collect cash bond and marriage solemnization fees, which are mandatory payments due to the MTC. Virgilio also did not collect the required solemnization fees in 57 marriages and the required clearance fee for 70 court clearances. The Team found that Virgilio and Norberta tampered with four official receipts representing fines and bond fees in the total amount of P30,600.00. Virgilio tampered an official receipt representing the payment of a court fine in the amount of P22,000.00. Virgilio failed to deposit the amount of P3,500.00 to the MTC's Mediation Fund. Virgilio served as the MTC's Process Server from December 3, 2010 to December 27, 2012 and accumulated Sheriffs Trust Fund collections in the total amount of P17,200.00 which was never deposited in the MTC's bank account.
Decision: In its Memorandum dated December 20, 2016, the OCA recommended that: respondent spouses be found guilty of grave misconduct, gross neglect of duty, and serious dishonesty; respondent Norberta be ordered dismissed from government service with cancellation of civil service eligibility, forfeiture of retirement benefits and other privileges, except accrued leave credits, if any, and with prejudice to reemployment in any branch or instrumentality of the government; considering that respondent Virgilio had already retired from the service, that the penalty of cancellation of eligibility, forfeiture of retirement benefits and other privileges, except accrued leave credits, if any, and with prejudice to re-employment in any branch or instrumentality of the government be instead imposed on him; and respondent Virgilio be directed to restitute the incurred cash shortages in the total amount of P779,643.15.
Ruling: The Supreme Court found that the respondents failed to meet the stringent standards governing the conduct of employees in the judiciary. The Court found that the OCA correctly concluded that Respondent Virgilio should be penalized for gross misconduct, serious dishonesty, and gross neglect of duty. The Court held that the findings of the Team and the evidence on record only warrant that Norberta be charged and penalized for gross misconduct and serious dishonesty for specific violations where she was found to have performed, or assisted Virgilio in the performance of, unlawful acts. The Court ruled that the respondents are liable for gross misconduct and serious dishonesty for tampering with official receipts, failure to remit collections, double withdrawal and unauthorized withdrawal of cash bonds. The Court held that Virgilio is solely liable for gross misconduct and serious dishonesty for tampering with an official receipt, failure to deposit amounts to the Mediation Fund and Sheriff's Trust Fund, and unauthorized withdrawal from the Fiduciary Fund account. The Court held that Virgilio should be held liable for gross negligence for failure to collect required fees and cash shortages which remain unexplained. The Court held that given the gravity of the offenses which Norberta committed, the penalty of dismissal from the service should be imposed. The Court held that Virgilio's retirement benefits are forfeited and required Virgilio to restitute the total amount of P779,643.15.
Verdict: WHEREFORE, Norberta R. Fortaleza is found GUILTY of gross misconduct and serious dishonesty. She is ordered DISMISSED from the service with forfeiture of all retirement benefits, except accrued leave credits. She is also disqualified from being re-employed in the government, including government-owned and controlled corporations. Virgilio M. Fortaleza is found GUILTY of gross misconduct, serious dishonesty, and gross neglect of duty. His retirement benefits, except accrued leave credits, are declared FORFEITED. He is likewise disqualified from being re-employed in the government, including government-owned and controlled corporations. Finally, Respondent Virgilio Fortaleza is ordered to RESTITUTE the incurred cash shortages in the total amount of P779,643.15 to the Municipal Trial Court of Catanauan, Quezon, within 30 days from notice. The case against the Respondent Virgilio M. Fortaleza is referred to the Office of the Ombudsman for appropriate action. SO ORDERED.

Case Title: PATRICIA HALAGUEÑA, MA. ANGELITA L. PULIDO, MA. TERESITA P. SANTIAGO, MARIANNE V. KATINDIG, BERNADETTA A. CABALQUINTO, LORNA B. TUGAS, MARY CHRISTINE A. VILLARETE, CYNTHIA A. STEHMEIER, ROSE ANA G. VICTA, NOEMI R. CRESENCIO AND OTHER FEMALE FLIGHT ATTENDANTS OF PHILIPPINE AIRLINES, PETITIONERS, VS. PHILIPPINE AIRLINES, INC., RESPONDENT.
Facts: Petitioners are members of Flight Attendants and Stewards Association of the Philippines (FASAP), the sole and exclusive bargaining representative of Philippine Airlines, Inc. (PAL) flight attendants, stewards, and pursers hired on different dates prior to November 22, 1996. On July 11, 2001, PAL and FASAP entered into a Collective Bargaining Agreement (CBA) incorporating the terms and conditions of employment of cabin attendants for the years 2000 to 2005 (PAL-FASAP 2000-2005 CBA). On July 29, 2004, petitioners filed a Petition for Declaratory Relief enjoining PAL from enforcing Section 144(A) of the PAL-FASAP 2000-2005 CBA. They sought the nullity of Section 144(A) for discriminating against female flight attendants in violation of the Constitution, the Labor Code, and the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. Section 144(A) provided that compulsory retirement shall be fifty-five (55) for females and sixty (60) for males. In its May 22, 2015 Decision, the trial court granted the petition for declaratory relief and declared Section 144(A) of the PAL-FASAP 2000-2005 CBA null and void for being discriminatory. The trial court held that Section 144(A) violates the Constitution, the Labor Code, and the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against Women for being discriminatory against women flight attendants. The trial court ruled that petitioners' rights cannot be bargained away and found that PAL failed to show any difference between male and female cabin attendants which would justify the implementation of the assailed provision. In a May 31, 2018 Decision, the Court of Appeals reversed and set aside the decision of the Regional Trial Court, and ruled in favor of PAL. The Court of Appeals ruled that since FASAP voluntarily assented to the questioned provision, there is a reasonable presumption that it is beneficial and acceptable to its members. The Court of Appeals ruled that the questioned provision is a valid and binding undertaking, as there was nothing illegal in the retirement clause warranting its nullification.
Decision: The Regional Trial Court granted the petition for declaratory relief and declared Section 144(A) of the PAL-FASAP 2000-2005 CBA null and void for being discriminatory. The Court of Appeals reversed the trial court's decision.
Ruling: The Supreme Court granted the Petition. The Court held that the fundamental equality of women and men before the law is enshrined and guaranteed by the Constitution, statutes, and international convention where the Philippines is a signatory. The Court held that respondent was not able to provide any reasonable basis for differentiating the compulsory retirement age for female cabin attendants at 55 years old and the male cabin attendants at 60 years old. The Court held that the Court of Appeals' reasoning supports the view that the compulsory retirement age for female cabin attendants was made lower than their male counterparts on the mere basis of their being women, which is discriminatory against women. The Court held that there is no proof that female cabin attendants, between 55 to 59 years old, do not have the necessary strength to open emergency doors, the agility to attend to passengers in cramped working conditions, and the stamina to withstand grueling flight schedules as compared with their male counterparts. The Court held that petitioners were able to prove that the enforcement of Section 144(A) of the PAL-FASAP 2000-2005 CBA is discriminatory against them, and thus prohibited by the Constitution, laws, and international conventions. The Court held that petitioners substantiated that they were discriminated upon when they were forced to retire at 55 years old while their male counterparts were compulsory retired at 60 years old. The Court held that the compulsory retirement provision in Section 144(A) of the PAL-FASAP 2000-2005 CBA is repugnant to the Constitution, the Labor Code, the Magna Carta of Women, and the CEDAW. The Court held that the said provision was not voluntarily agreed upon by petitioners. The Court held that contracts and its stipulations, whose cause, object, or purpose is contrary to law, morals, good customs, public order, or public policy, are void, thus Section 144(A) of the PAL-FASAP 2000-2005 CBA is void for being contrary to the Constitution, laws, international convention, and public policy.
Verdict: ACCORDINGLY, the Petition for Review is GRANTED. The May 31, 2018 Decision and November 19, 2018 Resolution of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CV No. 107085 are REVERSED and SET ASIDE. The May 22, 2015 Decision and October 9, 2015 Resolution of the Regional Trial Court of Makati City, Branch 59, in Civil Case No. 04-886, are AFFIRMED and REINSTATED. SO ORDERED.

Case Title: JEREMY REYES Y COLLANO, PETITIONER, VS. PEOPLE OF THE PHILIPPINES, RESPONDENT.
Facts: This case stemmed from four (4) Informations filed before the RTC charging Reyes with Illegal Possession of Firearms and Ammunition, as defined and penalized under Section 28 (a) in relation to Section 28 (e)(l) of RA 10591, and Reyes and accused Lorenz Christian Alano with Illegal Sale of Dangerous Drugs, and Alano with Illegal Possession of Dangerous Drugs and Illegal Possession of Equipment, Instrument, Apparatus, and Other Paraphernalia for Dangerous Drugs. The prosecution alleged that on March 25, 2017, pursuant to a tip of a confidential asset that a certain "Jer Jer" (later identified as Reyes), was engaged in selling drugs, members of the Sta. Maria Police Station organized a buy-bust operation with PO1 Genesis Tolentino as the poseur buyer. When the team arrived, they frisked Reyes and recovered from him the buy-bust money and an improvised gun loaded with ammunition. Upon subsequent verification with the Firearms and Explosives Office of the National Police Commission, it was discovered that Reyes had no authority to carry or possess any firearms, and that he was not a licensed firearm holder of any kind and caliber. For his part, Reyes denied the charges against him and claimed that during that time, he was at the house of Alano to invite him to attend a bible study. Thereafter, five armed men forcibly entered the house and ordered them to lie face down on the ground while they searched for marijuana. The police asset sealed a plastic sachet of marijuana and placed it on a table. Reyes claimed that he heard someone say that a bullet was found, after which, the police asset hit him with a belt, cursed him, and asked him if there was a gun in the house.
Decision: In a Joint Judgment dated September 7, 2018, the RTC found Reyes guilty beyond reasonable doubt of Illegal Possession of Firearms and Ammunition. The RTC ruled that the prosecution was able to prove all the elements of the crime charged since it was established that Reyes was found in possession of an improvised gun loaded with ammunition, and that based on the Certification dated June 19, 2017 issued by the Firearms and Explosive Office, he was not a licensed or registered firearm holder of any kind or caliber. The RTC acquitted Reyes of the other charges for failure of the prosecution to prove the fourth link in the chain of custody over the seized items. In a Decision dated July 10, 2020, the CA affirmed the RTC ruling in toto. It held that there was a valid search incidental to a lawful arrest as it was made following a buy-bust operation and that the police officers were justified in searching Reyes of any concealed weapon that he may use to facilitate his escape.
Ruling: The Supreme Court denied the petition. The Court held that the prosecution was able to establish beyond reasonable doubt all the elements of the crime of Illegal Possession of Firearms and Ammunition as it was proven that petitioner was in possession of an improvised gun loaded with ammunition and the Certification issued by the Firearms and Explosives Office revealed that Reyes was not a licensed/registered firearm holder of any kind or caliber. The Court held that the search made by the apprehending officers on Reyes, being contemporaneous to a valid warrantless arrest, incidental to a legitimate buy-bust operation was legal, and thereby making all the items seized therefrom admissible in evidence. The Court held that the failure of the prosecution to prove compliance with the chain of custody rule for illegal drugs under Section 21 of RA 9165 does not amount to failure to prove the crime of illegal possession of firearms and ammunition, if the latter charge does not go into the very transaction for which it was discovered. The Court held that the application of the chain of custody rule under Section 21 of RA 9165 has not been extended to other objects seized. The Court held that if the proffered evidence is unique, readily identifiable, and relatively resistant to change, that foundation need only consist of testimony by a witness with knowledge that the evidence is what the proponent claims. The Court modified the sentence and sentenced Reyes to suffer the penalty of imprisonment for an indeterminate period of eight (8) years and one (1) day of prision mayor, as minimum, to ten (10) years, eight (8) months, and one (1) day of prision mayor, as maximum.
Verdict: ACCORDINGLY, the instant petition is DENIED. The Decision dated July 10, 2020 and the Resolution dated February 4, 2021 of the Court of Appeals in CA-G.R. CR No. 42825 are AFFIRMED with MODIFICATION. Petitioner Jeremy Reyes y Collano is hereby found GUILTY beyond reasonable doubt of the crime of Illegal Possession of Firearms and Ammunition, as defined and penalized under Section 28 (a) in relation to Section 28 (e) (1) of Republic Act No. 10591, otherwise known as the "Comprehensive Firearms and Ammunition Regulation Act." In addition, he is sentenced to suffer the penalty of imprisonment for an indeterminate period of eight (8) years and one (1) day of prision mayor, as minimum, to ten (10) years, eight (8) months, and one (1) day of prision mayor, as maximum. SO ORDERED.
